column1: Out in the forest stood a pretty little Fir Tree. It had a good place; it could have sunlight
column3: and all around grew many larger comrades—pines as well as firs. But the little Fir Tree wished ardently to become greater. It did not care for the warm sun and the fresh air; it took no notice of the peasant children
column5: when they had come out to look for strawberries and raspberries. The children often came with a whole basketful
column6: or with a string of berries which they had strung on a straw. Then they would sit down by the little Fir Tree and say
column7: "How pretty and small this one is!" The Fir Tree did not like that at all.Next year he had grown bigger
column8: and the following year he was taller still."Oh
column9: if I were only as tall as the others!" sighed the little Fir. "Then I would spread my branches far around and look out from my crown into the wide world. The birds would then build nests in my boughs
column10: and when the wind blew I would nod grandly."
